metadata.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Corporation of Calcutta

facts.text: On July 1, 1952, the Corporation of Calcutta made an application for summons under s. 488 of Bengal Act III of 1923 against the Director of Rationing and Distribution representing the Food Department of the Government of West Bengal for using premises No. 259, Chitpur Road, Upper, for storing rice etc. without a licence under s. 386 for 1951-52.
The facts alleged by the prosecution were not denied by the Department.
Second Municipal Magistrate, Calcutta acquitted the accused on December 15, 1953, relying on Corporation of Calcutta v. Sub-Postmaster, holding s. 386 does not bind Government.

Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 282 of 1954 set aside acquittal on February 9, 1955, distinguishing prior decision and holding State bound unless excluded expressly or by necessary implication.
Special leave to appeal granted in September 1955.
Storing rice was under Bengal Rationing Order, 1943, for rationing and distribution by Food Department.

legal_issues.text: Whether State is a person within the meaning of s. 386 of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923.
Does the Constitution make any change in the principle of prerogative as part of the common law.

Does Art. 372 of the Constitution keep the existing law intact, i.e., the law as declared in L.R. 73 I.A. 271 that the Crown is not bound by any statute unless expressly named or by necessary implication.

petitioner_arguments.text: State is not a person within s. 386; word 'person' does not include State; Art. 300 unnecessary if it did.
Crown not bound by statute unless expressly named or by necessary implication; this common law rule continues post-Constitution via Art. 372.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Province of Bombay v. Municipal Corporation of the City of Bombay, L.R. 73 I.A. 271 (Privy Council); Art. 372 Constitution

petitioner_arguments.text: Activity is governmental function (rationing), not trading.
No necessary implication binds State; Act operates without binding Government.

respondent_arguments.text: State is a person capable of rights/duties; bound unless expressly excluded.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 300 Constitution; Salmond 11th Ed. p.35; A.I.R. 1955 Nag. 177; A.I.R. 1956 Pat. 91

respondent_arguments.text: No royal prerogative post-Constitution; republican setup inconsistent; immunity only for sovereign acts, not trading.
Bound by necessary implication; s.386 for public health; express exemptions elsewhere (s.126).

court_reasoning.text: Common law rule that sovereign not bound unless expressly or by necessary implication continues post-Constitution via Art.372 as law in force; not dependent on monarchy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Immunity based on public policy, applies to Republics (US cases); Calcutta HC erred in following Madras view over Privy Council.

court_reasoning.text: Rule is of construction, presumed legislative intent; applies to executive acts like rationing, governmental function not trade.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sarkar J.: Rule protects Crown rights/title/interest when acting in executive duties.

court_reasoning.text: Prerogative rule does not survive Republic; ordinary construction: State bound unless exempt expressly/necessary implication; here penal fine goes to State, exempt by implication.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Wanchoo J.: State cannot be imprisoned/fined meaningfully; s.81 fines to State.

court_reasoning.text: No necessary implication; Act not frustrated without binding State.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.386 concerns premises use, not solely adulteration.

holdings.text: State not bound by s.386 Calcutta Municipal Act 1923 unless expressly or by necessary implication; rule of construction continues.
Constitution does not alter prerogative principle as common law rule of construction; preserved by Art.372.
No necessary implication binds State to penal provision; cannot prosecute State effectively.

precedents_cited.case_name: Province of Bombay v. Municipal Corporation of the City of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Crown/Govt not bound unless expressly named or necessary implication; binding pre-Constitution.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bell v. Municipal Commissioners for the City of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Govt bound unless excluded; minority view rejected.

precedents_cited.case_name: Corporation of Calcutta v. Sub-Postmaster, Dharamtala Post Office
United States v. United Mine Workers of America
precedents_cited.relevance: Rule of construction applies in Republic.
Executive Govt not bound unless intention apparent.

statutes_cited.name: Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires licence for storing rice; penal for non-compliance; fines to State; some express exemptions.

statutes_cited.name: Calcutta Municipal Act, 1951 (West Bengal Act XXXIII)
Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Continues laws in force including common law; State as person for suits.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside; Magistrate's acquittal confirmed; prosecution misconceived as State not bound by s.386.

key_quotes.text: "No person shall use or permit to be used any premises... without... a licence... namely... storing... rice..."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The king is not bound by any act of Parliament, unless he be named therein by special and particular words.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Blackstone on common law rule followed.

key_quotes.text: The rule of interpretation of statutes that the State is not bound by a statute, unless it is so provided in express terms or by necessary implication, is still good law.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Sinha CJ holding on continuity post-Constitution.

key_quotes.text: By necessary implication, the State is exempt from all penal statutes and provisions providing for sentences of imprisonment or death.
key_quotes.speaker: court
